thread.title: Longhorns ranked fourth in Big 12 coaches poll
thread.title_full: Longhorns ranked fourth in Big 12 coaches poll - San Antonio Express-News

author: Nick Moyle
title: Longhorns ranked fourth in Big 12 coaches poll
text:
Photo: Eric Gay, Associated Press Image 1 of / 11 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 11 10. Texas Tech
Tubby Smith's Red Raiders didn't get much love from his fellow coaches.
Texas Tech finished a woeful 3-15 in Big 12 play last season and didn't have a single player average over 10.5 points per game. This team is in line for some progression though; the five freshmen who played significant minutes last season should be better prepared to handle the rigors of Big 12 conference play. 10. Texas Tech
Tubby Smith's Red Raiders didn't get much love from his fellow coaches.
Texas Tech finished a woeful 3-15 in Big 12 play last season and didn't have a single player average over 10.5 points... Photo: Eric Gay, Associated Press Image 2 of 11 9. TCU
TCU hasn't made the NCAA Tournament since 1998. That won't change this year.
The Horned Frogs' four Big 12 victories came over Texas Tech, Kansas State and Oklahoma State — not exactly the Big 12 murderer's row. Their three best players all graduated, leaving TCU scrambling to replace more than 30 points of production each night. 9. TCU
TCU hasn't made the NCAA Tournament since 1998. That won't change this year.
The Horned Frogs' four Big 12 victories came over Texas Tech, Kansas State and Oklahoma State — not exactly the Big 12... Photo: Mike Stone, Associated Press Image 3 of 11 8. Kansas State
With all that's happened in Manhattan this offseason, it's a wonder the Wildcats garnered enough points to rank No. 8.
Last year's leading scorer Marcus Foster, along with Malek Harris and Tre Harris, were kicked off the team, while sophomore guards Jevon Thomas and Nigel Johnson elected to transfer. Those losses, in addition to the graduations of Nino Williams (11.4 PPG, 5.3 RPG) and Thomas Gipson (11.3 PPG, 5.3 RPG), leave coach Bruce Weber with little chance of contending. 8. Kansas State
With all that's happened in Manhattan this offseason, it's a wonder the Wildcats garnered enough points to rank No. 8.
Last year's leading scorer Marcus Foster, along with Malek Harris and Tre... Photo: Charlie Riedel, Associated Press Image 4 of 11 7. Oklahoma State
Despite an 8-10 record in conference play and a freefall to the finish, Oklahoma St. was gifted with a No. 9 seed in the NCAA Tournament.
It was a handout that might allow their talent to finally shine through. Wrong. They lost to Oregon 79-73 in the round of 64, putting a cap on a disappointing season.
Now, with Le'Bryan Nash (17.2 PPG, 5.7 RPG), Anthony Hickey and Michael Cobbins gone, the backcourt duo of senior Phil Forte and freshman Jawun Evans will be relied on to carry a team that seems to underachieve every year. 7. Oklahoma State
Despite an 8-10 record in conference play and a freefall to the finish, Oklahoma St. was gifted with a No. 9 seed in the NCAA Tournament.
It was a handout that might allow their talent to... Photo: Brody Schmidt /Associated Press Image 5 of 11 6. West Virginia
The Mountaineers were a mainstay in the Top 25 last season behind a balanced effort that saw six players average at least seven points.
Juwan Staten is in Golden State, meaning they lack a reliable scoring presence, but this a team which thrives on defense. West Virginia led the nation both in steal rate and opponent turnover percentage, and scrapped their way into a ride to the sweet 16.
With a strong returning core, the Mountaineers should be doing some dancing come March. 6. West Virginia
The Mountaineers were a mainstay in the Top 25 last season behind a balanced effort that saw six players average at least seven points.
Juwan Staten is in Golden State, meaning they lack a... Photo: Rod Aydelotte, FRE / Associated Press Image 6 of 11 5. Baylor
Baylor's 24-win season and No. 3 seed in the NCAA tournament don't mean a whole heck of a lot when you consider that they lost to No. 14 Georgia St. in the Round of 64.
They lost key seniors Kenny Chery and Royce O’Neal, but bring back Taurean Prince and Rico Gathers, perhaps the Big 12's most dyanmic inside-outside duo. Gathers will be complimented in the post by sophomore Jonathan Motley and 7-foot transfer Jo Acuil, which should deter teams from attacking too much.
This team is stocked with talent. Now, can coach Scott Drew put it all together? 5. Baylor
Baylor's 24-win season and No. 3 seed in the NCAA tournament don't mean a whole heck of a lot when you consider that they lost to No. 14 Georgia St. in the Round of 64.
They lost key seniors Kenny... Photo: Rod Aydelotte /Waco Tribune-Herald Image 7 of 11 4. Texas
Shaka Smart inherits a squad with skilled upperclassmen, but several question marks.
The Longhorns shot just 43.3 percent last year, 184th among Division I teams. The offensive struggles of a season ago are troublesome, but Smart should instill some of his wisdom into a team that could thrive under his tutelage. 4. Texas
Shaka Smart inherits a squad with skilled upperclassmen, but several question marks.
The Longhorns shot just 43.3 percent last year, 184th among Division I teams. The offensive struggles of a season... Photo: Edward A. Ornelas, Staff / San Antonio Express-News Image 8 of 11 3. Iowa State
Fred Hoiberg is off coaching Derrick Rose and Jimmy Butler in Chicago, so replacement Steve Prohm came to town to take the reigns of a team with lofty expectations.
Led by the talented triumvirate of Geroges Niang, Monte Morris and Jameel McKay, the Cyclones were the only team who could siphon a first-place vote away from the Jayhawks.
Despite the new leadership, the Cyclones are expected to maintain their high-octane offense and impose their scoring will on opponents. Now, they just have to avoid another first-round letdown. 3. Iowa State
Fred Hoiberg is off coaching Derrick Rose and Jimmy Butler in Chicago, so replacement Steve Prohm came to town to take the reigns of a team with lofty expectations.
Led by the talented... Photo: Orlin Wagner, STF / Associated Press Image 9 of 11 2. Oklahoma
Led by All-American Buddy Hield, the Sooners are looking to one-up their run to the Sweet 16 from a year ago.
Oklahoma returns nearly its entire core, sans TaShawn Thomas, which will hurt the team's frontcourt depth, but shouldn't be enough to derail a what could be Lon Kruger's best season at the helm. 2. Oklahoma
Led by All-American Buddy Hield, the Sooners are looking to one-up their run to the Sweet 16 from a year ago.
Oklahoma returns nearly its entire core, sans TaShawn Thomas, which will hurt the... Photo: Getty Images Image 10 of 11 1. Kansas
In the Big 12, placing Kansas at the top is as natural as breathing.
The Jayhawks received all but one first place vote, and with four starters returning from a 25-win team, plus highly-touted freshman Cheick Diallo in town, it's no surprise that KU is expected to capture another Big 12 title.
Diallo hasn't been cleared to officially play this season, but if the NCAA grants him eligibility, the 6-foot-9 Mali native could be the final piece that propels Bill Self's team back into the Final Four for the first time since 2012. 1. Kansas
In the Big 12, placing Kansas at the top is as natural as breathing.
The Jayhawks received all but one first place vote, and with four starters returning from a 25-win team, plus highly-touted... Photo: Tony Gutierrez /Associated Press Image 11 of 11 Longhorns ranked fourth in Big 12 coaches poll 1 / 11 Back to Gallery The Big 12 released its coaches poll Thursday morning and — shocker — the Kansas Jayhawks are No. 1.
Kansas has captured the Big 12 regular season title an astonishing 11 consecutive seasons and 13 of the past 14 overall, and Bill Self has a cache of immense talent at his disposal to expand upon those totals this year.
The Longhorns — who finished 20-14 last season and earned a No. 11-seed in the NCAA Tournament, but met a swift end at the hands of No. 6 Butler in the Round of 64 — rank fourth with 51 points, 30 behind the Jayhawks.
Click through the slides above to see where the coaches ranked each Big 12 team heading into the 2015-2016 season.
